instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.820-3642: What is 820-3642? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3642</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> almost full short
threads.message:
Water damaged around <CAPACITOR>C9687</CAPACITOR>, down below from DC Jack. Cleaned in UC, tried booting. 55mA. Pulled <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> out, found <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.0017 diode mode. Tried injecting 3.3V there, <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> gets warm.

Am I screwed? Maybe just for test lift all caps in damage area where liquid was?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3642</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> almost full short
threads.message: If you started the board without <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> soldered on, forget it this is done. If <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted and the CPU is all that gets hot, this can also RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3642</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> almost full short
threads.message:
No, I haven't started without <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>. What I found partially shorted is: 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0.017
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0.016
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0.060

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3642</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> almost full short
threads.message: Measure resistance to ground in ohms. Shorted is shorted however.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3642</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> almost full short
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3642</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> almost full short
threads.message:
Looks like bad PCH.
Both power rails go there and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is controlled by it too.
